On Thu, 03 Jun 2004 08:58:12 -0700, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> However, an appendix isn't a neuron.  The likelihood of a neuron being able
> to be coopted into useful service is much higher than the chances of finding
> a use for the appendix.  So the analogy doesn't quite hold.

I don't think Colin and Ken were arguing exclusively for a single
neuron to be adapted.  I think they were referring to whole chunks of
networks suddenly being connected and becoming useful, which *would*
be akin to an appendix suddenly springing into service.

But again, if we're just talking about a single neuron, why not just
allow for a single mutation to bring about that new functionality,
instead of keeping redundant features around, waiting for them to be
connected?  The former is much more efficient than the latter.

If you're talking about just connecting a single neuron into the
network that was just hanging around unconnected beforehand, that's
logically equivalent to mutating a new neuron and two connections
between two existing neurons, right?  Why not add this type of
mutation to your GA, rather than have a whole bunch of neurons that
don't do *anything* until a connection mutates to link them up with
the rest of the functioning network?

Derek
